questions.text: Prion Disease (Fatal Neurodegenerative Disease) is caused by?
questions.solution:
Prion diseases are protein conformation diseases transmitted by altering the conformation, and hence the physical properties, of proteins endogenous to the host such as human prion-related protein (PrP)

Prion diseases are caused by misfolded proteins (prions), where a normal protein undergoes a conformational change into a misfolded, pathogenic form that can induce other proteins to misfold, leading to fatal neurodegeneration.

Prion diseases, are fatal neurodegenerative diseases characterized by spongiform changes, astrocytic gliomas, and neuronal loss resulting from the deposition of insoluble protein aggregates in neural cells. E.g Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans

A) Defective Translation during Synthesis - Defective translation refers to errors that occur during the process of translating mRNA into protein. While translation errors can lead to improperly formed proteins, prion diseases are not caused by translation errors but rather by the misfolding of a correctly synthesized protein. Prion diseases are related to post-synthesis changes in the protein's conformation, not errors in the initial protein production.

B) Single Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP) It is variations at a single position in the DNA sequence. Some inherited prion diseases (like Familial Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) are associated with genetic mutations, including SNPs in the PRNP gene, which encodes the prion protein. However, prion diseases themselves are primarily caused by the misfolding of the prion protein rather than the presence of SNPs. The mutation increases susceptibility but is not the direct cause of the disease.

D) Infection due to Bacteria : caused by harmful bacteria invading and multiplying in the body. Prion diseases are not caused by bacteria but by abnormal protein folding. Prions are non-living infectious agents, unlike bacteria, viruses, or parasites, and do not involve an external pathogen like bacteria.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 5, Page number:43

questions.text: In all reactions mentioned below, S-Adenosyl Methionine is used except
questions.solution:
Methionine reacts with ATP forming S Adenosyl Methionine (Active Methionine). S-adenosyl-methionine serves as a methyl-group donor for many enzyme-catalyze reactions.

Phenylalanine to tyrosine reaction catalyzed by Phenylalanine Hydroxylase enzyme. This reaction requires Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) as co factor. It does not require SAM - S adenosyl Methionine.

A) Serotonin to Melatonin conversion involves methylation in the biosynthesis and S-Adenosyl Methionine (SAM) acts as a methyl group donor during the conversion of serotonin to melatonin.

B) Norepinephrine to epinephrine is catalyzed by the enzyme phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT), and S-Adenosyl Methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor in this methylation reaction.

D)In the biosynthesis of choline from ethanolamine, S-Adenosyl Methionine (SAM) is required as a methyl donor in the series of methylation steps.

Biosynthesis of S-adenosylmethionine from methionine and ATP is catalyzed by methionine adenosyl transferase (MAT). Human tissues contain three MAT isoenzymes: MAT-1 and MAT-3 of liver and MAT-2 of non hepatic tissues.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 29, page number: 298-309

choices.text: Every Third Amino Acid in Collagen structure is Glycine
In collagen structure of Triple Helix, Covalent cross linking of modified Lysyl Residues provides stability.
Zn containing Lysyl Oxidase has important role in covalent bonding with cross linking of Polypeptide chain.
Hydroxylation of Proline require vitamin C as Cofactor.

questions.solution:
Lysyl Oxidase is Cu containing enzyme that converts ε-amino groups to aldehydes. The aldehydes can either undergo an aldol condensation to form a C-C double bond or form a Schiff base with the ε-amino group of an unmodified lysyl residue, which is subsequently reduced to form a C-N single bond. These covalent bonds cross-link the individual polypeptides and imbue the fiber with exceptional strength and rigidity.

A) In collagen structure of Triple Helix every third amino acid is glycine. Staggering of the three strands provides appropriate positioning of the requisite glycine throughout the helix. Collagen is also rich in proline and hydroxyproline, yielding a repetitive Gly-X-Y pattern where Y is Hydroxyproline or proline.

B) Additional stability is provided by covalent cross-links formed between modified lysyl residues both within and between polypeptide chains along with Glycine & Proline and Hydroxyproline

D) Procollagen are hydroxylated by prolyl hydroxylase and lysyl hydroxylase, enzymes that require ascorbic acid (vitamin C); Hydroxyprolyl and hydroxylysyl residues provide additional hydrogen-bonding capability that stabilizes the mature protein. Thus in Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy), Collagen maturation is deficient leading to improper wound healing, bleeding gums etc.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 5, Page number. 44

choices.text: I - b, II - a, III - c, IV - d
I - c, II - d, III - a, IV - b
I - b, II - d, III - a, IV - c
I - d, II - b, III - a, IV - c

questions.solution:
Alanine is a key gluconeogenic amino acid (Glucose Alanine Cycle). The rate of hepatic gluconeogenesis from Alanine is far higher than from all other amino acids. the capacity of the liver for gluconeogenesis from Alanine does not reach saturation until the Alanine concentration reaches 20 to 30 times its normal physiologic level.

Ketogenic Aminoacid - Ketogenic amino acids are primarily involved in the production of acetyl-CoA or acetoacetate, which are precursors to ketone bodies.

Unlike glucogenic amino acids, they do not contribute to gluconeogenesis (the process of generating glucose).

There are two amino acids that are exclusively ketogenic: Leucine, Lysine

In addition to these, several other amino acids are both ketogenic and glucogenic. These include: Isoleucine, Phenylalanine, Tryptophan, Tyrosine

L Glutamate is the only amino acid which undergoes oxidative deamination.

Each Amino Transferases is specific for one pair of substrate but nonspecific for the other pairs.  Alanine is substrate for Glutamate Amino Transferases, the Alpha amino nitrogen from all amino acids that undergoes transamination can be concentrated in Glutamate. Transamination occurs via "Ping Pong Mechanism".

All of the common amino acids except lysine, threonine, proline, and hydroxyproline participate in transamination

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition, Chapter 28, Page number: 282-283

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 25, Page number: 410

questions.text: Formation of Xanthurenate in tryptophan Amino Acid Metabolism is diagnostic marker for which vitamin Deficiency?
questions.solution:
In Tryptophan Amino Acid Metabolism, Conversion of 3 hydroxykynurenin to 3 hydroxyanthranilate requires kynureninase. Kynureninase requires Pyridoxal Phosphate for its action. In deficiency of Vitamin B6 this reaction not occurs thus 3 hydroxykynurenin converted to xanthurenate, level increased and excreted in Urine. So Tryptophan load test is diagnostic test for Vitamin B6 Deficiency.

Option B) In deficiency of Tryptophan, Niacin production is deficient. Niacin Deficiency leads to Pellagra. So Tryptophan deficiency can lead to Pellagra like symptoms which is seen in Hartnup Disease in which there is impaired Intestinal and Renal Transport of Tryptophan. It has no role in more production of Xanthurenate. Tryptophan Oxygenase is feedback inhibited by NADPH

Option C) Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) in Amino Acid Metabolism

Riboflavin is essential for the production of flavo coenzymes, such as FMN (flavin mononucleotide) and FAD (flavin adenine dinucleotide). These cofactors are involved in various redox reactions, which are crucial for energy production and metabolism.

Riboflavin is involved in the oxidation-reduction reactions that are part of the metabolism of amino acids. For example, it plays a role in: Deamination: The removal of amino groups from amino acids, which is essential for converting amino acids into energy or other metabolites. Transamination: The transfer of amino groups between amino acids and α-keto acids, a key process in amino acid synthesis and catabolism.

Pantothenic Acid (Vitamin B5) in Amino Acid Metabolism: Pantothenic acid is a precursor to coenzyme A (CoA), which is critical for various metabolic pathways.

CoA is involved in the synthesis and oxidation of fatty acids, as well as the metabolism of carbohydrates and amino acids.

In Amino Acid Metabolism, Pantothenic acid contributes to Acylation Reactions: CoA participates in the activation of fatty acids and their subsequent breakdown, which is interconnected with amino acid metabolism, especially in energy production.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 29, page number: 295-296

questions.text: The Program which simulate the interaction that takes place between Protein and Inhibitor is called as
questions.solution:
Molecular docking programs simulate the interactions that take place when a protein encounters a substrate, inhibitor, or other ligand. It is part of molecular Modeling.

Molecular modeling is also employed to infer the structure of proteins for which x-ray crystallographic or NMR structures are not yet available.

Molecular dynamics programs can be useful to simulate the conformational dynamic of a protein and the manner in which factors such as temperature, pH, ionic strength, or amino acid substitutions influence these motions. If the protein being analyze is homologous to one whose structure has already been solve, one can phase diffraction data without using heavy atoms by performing molecular replacement using the existing structure as a scaffold.

Molecular mimicking (or molecular mimicry) refers to the phenomenon where one molecule, typically a pathogen (like a virus or bacterium), mimics the structure or sequence of host molecules to evade the immune system. This similarity can confuse the host's immune response, causing it to fail to properly recognize and attack the pathogen.

While this can help pathogens survive within a host, it can also lead to autoimmune diseases. In these cases, the immune system, having been primed to attack the pathogen, may mistakenly target the host's own tissues, as they resemble the pathogen's molecular structures.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 5, Page number: 41-42

questions.text: 4 year old child having pale blue iris, pale hair, blurring of vision identified with Deficiency of Tyrosine Metabolism. What is probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Clinical History is suggestive of Albinism. Tyrosine metabolism, the first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme Tyrosinase. Tyrosinase again acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin.

Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Occulocutaneous Albinism is characterized by a reduction or complete lack of Melanin pigment in the skin hair and eyes. This leads to decreased visual activity, photophobia.

Option B) Tyrosinemia II is caused due to deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical Findings include keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia.

Option C) Alkaptonuria is caused by defect in Homogentisate oxidase. Presented with dark color urine with bluish black pigmentation in connective tissue.

Option D) Phenylketonuria is caused by deficiency of Phenylalanine hydroxylase required for conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Infants have low IQ and hypopigmentation.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 25, page number:408, 405-406

questions.text: Tetrahydrofolic Acid is the coenzyme of?
questions.solution:
Tetrahydrofolic acid (THF) is a coenzyme involved in one-carbon transfer reactions, which are crucial for the synthesis of amino acids, nucleotides, and other biomolecules. It plays a key role in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine and the formation of glutamic acid through the folate cycle.

The formation of glutamic acid (also known as glutamate) is a crucial process in amino acid metabolism. Glutamic acid is synthesized through various pathways, often involving transamination reactions or the incorporation of one-carbon units, but tetrahydrofolic acid (THF) does not directly catalyze the formation of glutamate

Formation of Glutamate in Relation to THF: THF is involved in transferring one-carbon units in various oxidation states (formyl, methylene, methyl groups).

Histidine Degradation and THF Role: Histidine degradation leads to the production of formiminoglutamate (FIGLU), which can be converted to glutamate with the help of THF.

THF accepts the formimino group from FIGLU to generate N⁵-formimino-THF, leading to the release of glutamate.

Reaction: FIGLU+THF→Glutamate+N⁵-formimino-THF

Option A) Transamination Reactions: These reactions typically involve pyridoxal phosphate (derived from Vitamin B6) as the coenzyme, not tetrahydrofolic acid.

Transamination reactions are critical biochemical processes in amino acid metabolism where an amino group (-NH₂) is transferred from one amino acid to a keto acid (an alpha-keto acid). These reactions are reversible and are key for the synthesis and degradation of amino acids.

Transfer of Amino Group:In a transamination reaction, an amino group from an amino acid is transferred to an α-keto acid, converting the amino acid into an α-keto acid and the α-keto acid into a new amino acid.

Enzymes Involved: The enzymes that catalyze these reactions are known as transaminases or aminotransferases. The most common transaminases are:

  1. Alanine transaminase (ALT): Catalyzes the conversion of alanine and α-ketoglutarate into pyruvate and glutamate.
  2. Aspartate transaminase (AST): Catalyzes the conversion of aspartate and α-ketoglutarate into oxaloacetate and glutamate.

Coenzyme Requirement: Transaminases require pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), a coenzyme derived from vitamin B6.

Option B) L Amino Acid Oxidase: This enzyme uses flavin mononucleotide (FMN) as a coenzyme, not THF.

Features of L-Amino Acid Oxidase: Reaction Catalyzed: LAAO catalyzes the oxidation of the amino group from L-amino acids (but not D-amino acids) to form an α-keto acid, releasing ammonia and hydrogen peroxide as byproducts.

Flavin Coenzyme:

  1. LAAO contains flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) as a prosthetic group, which is essential for its oxidative function.
  2. FAD acts as an electron carrier in the reaction, accepting electrons from the amino acid and transferring them to molecular oxygen (O₂), reducing it to hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂).
  3. Option C) Glutamate Dehydrogenase: This enzyme primarily uses NAD⁺ or NADP⁺ as a coenzyme, not tetrahydrofolic acid.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry Chapter 29, Page 293, Chapter 44 Page number: 536, 545

questions.text: Iron Sulphur protein is present in Electron Transport Chain Complex
questions.solution:
Iron-sulphur (Fe-S) proteins are found in Complex I, II, and III of the electron transport chain. They play a crucial role in transferring electrons within these complexes. Complex IV does not contain iron-sulfur proteins; it relies primarily on copper centers and heme groups for electron transfer.

Metal ions that participate in redox reactions are bound as organometallic complexes such as the prosthetic groups heme or iron-sulfur clusters. The iron atoms of many metalloproteins facilitate the catalysis of oxidation-reduction, or redox, reactions.

Other Example of Fe and Mo containing metalloenzyme sulfite oxidase is located in the mitochondria, where it catalyzes the oxidation of the sulfite generated by the catabolism of sulfur containing biomolecules to sulfate.

Class I cytochrome p 450 systems consist of an FAD-containing reductase enzyme, an iron sulfur (Fe2S2) protein, and the P450 heme protein.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry chapter 7 & 13, Page number: 62, 122

choices.text: No net Negative or Positive Charge
Isoelectric Point is between two pka value

questions.text: Properties of Zwitter ions are all except
questions.solution:
Zwitterions are one example of an isoelectric species. The form of a molecule that has an equal number of positive and negative charges and thus is electrical neutral. The isoelectric pH, also called the isoelectric point or pI, is the pH midway between pKa values for the ionizations on either side of the isometric species.

Zwitterions have very less Migration in Electric Field and so they are easy to precipitate.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, Chapter 3, page number: 20 -21

questions.text: Vitamin E Deficiency leads to all except?
questions.solution:
Vitamin E Deficiency leads to Resorption of Fetus, Hemolytic Anemia and Testicular Atrophy. It has no role in Cell Differentiation.

α-tocopherol (vitamin E), act as scavengers of free radicals and reduce the toxicity of oxygen.

A deficiency of vitamin E enhances the hepatic necrosis of the choline deficiency type of fatty liver. Added vitamin E or a source of selenium has a protective effect by combating lipid peroxidation.

Premature infants are born with inadequate reserves of the vitamin. The erythrocyte membranes are abnormally fragile as a result of lipid peroxidation, leading to hemolytic anemia.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 44, Page number: 540

questions.text: A 50 years old male patient with history of chronic alcoholism develops Mental Confusion, Gait Ataxia, Nystagmus, Loss of memory, Hallucinations and Ophthalmoplegia. Which test is important to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
In given case scenario, Mental confusion, gait ataxia, nystagmus, loss of memory, hallucinations, and ophthalmoplegia are indicative of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, a condition associated with thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcoholics.

Chronic consumption of Alcohol leads to damage to GI tract, decreased absorption of Thiamine. Diuretic action of alcohol leads to loss of water soluble vitamins like Thiamine in Urine. Liver Damage in Chronic Alcoholism leads to improper storage of nutrients.

Thiamine is a coenzyme for several enzymes, including transketolase, which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway. Measuring erythrocyte transketolase levels can help diagnose thiamine deficiency, as low levels of this enzyme activity are typically seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Option B) FIGLU Test: The formiminoglutamate (FIGLU) test is used to diagnose folic acid deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency. FIGLU (Formiminoglutamate) is an intermediate compound formed during the metabolism of the amino acid histidine. FIGLU is normally converted to glutamate with the help of folic acid (specifically, tetrahydrofolate, a form of folate), which acts as a coenzyme.

In deficiency of folic acid or vitamin B12 (which is needed for folate metabolism), FIGLU cannot be properly converted to glutamate and instead accumulates in the body.This excess FIGLU is then excreted in the urine, and its elevated levels in urine can be detected using the FIGLU test.

Option C) Urine Xanthurenic Acid level: This test is used to assess vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency. It is not directly related to the diagnosis of thiamine deficiency.

Option D) Schilling Test: The Schilling test is used to diagnose vitamin B12 absorption issues, specifically in cases of pernicious anemia or malabsorption syndromes.

Procedure for Schilling test:

  1. Oral Vitamin B12 Without Intrinsic Factor The patient is given a small dose of radioactive vitamin B12 orally (for tracing purposes).
  2. After that, the patient receives a vitamin B12 injection to saturate the body's B12 stores, ensuring that the radioactive B12 taken orally is not absorbed into tissues but rather excreted in the urine if absorbed properly.
  3. Urine Collection: The patient's urine is collected for 24 hours, and the amount of radioactive vitamin B12 excreted is measured.
  4. Oral Vitamin B12 With Intrinsic Factor

If the first stage shows poor absorption, the test is repeated, but this time with intrinsic factor added to the oral radioactive vitamin B12.

If adding intrinsic factor corrects the absorption issue (i.e., the patient excretes normal amounts of B12 in the urine), it suggests that the patient has pernicious anemia, as the body is unable to produce enough intrinsic factor for B12 absorption.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, chapter 32, Page number: 530

questions.text: 40 Years old patient presented with fatigue, generalize weakness, Neuropathic Pain. Laboratory study reveals Macrocytic Anemia and elevated level of Homocysteine with normal level of Methylmalonic acid. Which is most likely deficit?
questions.solution:
As shown in case history, Generalize Fatigue, Neurological Manifestations and Macrocytic Anemia is seen in deficiency of Folic Acid and Vitamin B12.

Remethylation of Homocysteine to Methionine requires THF (Folic Acid) and the isomerization of Methylmalonyl Coenzyme A to succinyl Coenzyme A which does not require Folic Acid.

So the elevated Homocysteine and normal methyalmalonic acid levels in given case history is suggestive of Folic Acids.

Iron Deficiency causes microcytic Anemia not macrocytic Anemia.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, Chapter 32, page number: 549

choices.text: PO4 Retention requires PO4 reduction therapy

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding Renal Osteodystrophy.
questions.solution:
In chronic Kidney disease leads to decreased ability to form active vitamin D. It also leads to increased retention of Phosphate. Low Vitamin D levels leads to Hypocalcemia due to decreased Intestinal Absorption and retention of Phosphate leads to Hyperphosphatemia.

Low Blood Ca level due to low Vitamin D level causes rise in in PTH and associated bone demineralization with release of Ca+2 and PO4-.This condition is known as Renal Osteodystrophy.

In Renal Osteodystrophy vitamin D supplementation should be accompanied with PO4- therapy which help to prevent further bone loss and precipitation of calcium phosphate crystals.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA Edition, chapter 32, page number: 542

choices.text: Helps in Reduction of HDL cholesterol
Increase the effect of Hormone Sensitive Lipase

questions.text: Role of Niacin in prevention of Cardiovascular Disease is due to?
questions.solution:
Niacin at dose of 1.5 g/day strongly inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue, the primary producer of circulating free fatty acids (FFA). The liver normally uses these circulating FFA as precursor for Triacylglycerol (TAG) synthesis.

Niacin decreased the production of VLDL and LDL. Niacin is useful in the treatment of Type IIb Hyperlipoproteinemia. Niacin also raises High Density Lipoprotein.

Free radicals contribute to oxidative stress, but niacin's effect on cholesterol metabolism is the main reason it is used to manage cardiovascular risk.

Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is an enzyme that breaks down stored triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol. Niacin does decrease the activity of HSL indirectly by inhibiting lipolysis.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SA EDITION, Chapter 32 Page number: 532
